text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

Coming to HBS, I
knew that I wanted

to work in fintech
and emerging markets.

Things like financial inclusion
and access motivates me.

I grew up in
Port-au-Prince in Haiti.

And I wanted to work in lower
or middle income countries that

had a lot of opportunities
so that I could learn.

I've worked in like Fortune
500 companies before.

And at some point in my
life, I thought that, oh,

aspiring to become partner
at a big accounting

firm or a big consulting
firm was something
that I wanted to do.

But I think quickly, I realized
that my personal experience

could be channeled to do
something greater and bigger.

One of the things
that CPD did to help

me make a better decision
was, one, providing data.

So there is aggregate
data about students

who have pursued startup
opportunities, the salaries

that they would be receiving,
the kind of bonus or stipend

that they may have received,
and the kind of geographies

in which they
went, and maybe did
internship turn into offers?

Or is there ongoing
support for people joining
these opportunities full-time?

So I think that
data was critical.

If I could talk to the
next RC class high level,

I would tell them to
keep an open mind.

The classes that
you choose to take

in the elective years,
the kind of opportunities

that you consider, the kind
of friendship that you make,

yes, it's very easy, and
it's important to have

your own sense of self and
your own sense of values.

But I think we are in a
place where we have people

from different
backgrounds for a reason.

And so I think
keeping an open mind

allows you to just
absorb all of that
and make something of their own.
